column3: This figure for 2016-17(BE) includes Interest Subsidy for Short Term Credit to Farmers to the tune of Rs. 15000 crore, which was earlier with the Department of Financial Services under the Ministry of Finance. The allocation for the same during 2015-16 BE was Rs. 13000 crore. Hence, the allocation noted for 2016-17 BE is not strictly comparable with that of earlier years allocation / spending.

column4: The Prime Minister Fasal Bima Yojana has been coined by combining earlier insurance schemes for farmers.  An allocation to the tune of Rs. 5,500 crore proposed in the Budget 2016-17, which shows an upward revision of the allocation from Rs, 2955 crore in 2016-17 RE.

The allocation for RKVY got slight increase in the current budget, which is far from satisfactory, however, due to change is fund sharing pattern, it is expected that the statesâ€™ would put relevant share (40 %) towards the programme.

The allocation for PMKSY (within MoA) has been increased from Rs. 1800 crore to Rs. 2340 core seems quite inadequate if one looks at the percentage of cultivable area under irrigation (46 %) in the country.

The declined allocation for NFSM in 2016-17 BE compared to 2014-15 (although the repriorisation in favour of Pulses Mission, with an additional allocation of Rs. 500 core, incentivizing farmers for pulse cultivation) seems the thrust of meeting the demand-supply mis-match of pulses in the country.

There has been a decline of allocation to the tune of Rs. 4584 crore in 2016-17 BE compared to 2015-16 RE under the head Food Subsidy. Also, there is nothing mentioned in the Budget Speech of the Finance Minister on Implementation of National Food Security Act (NFSA) in the country, which shows that government is not serious about the implementation of NFSA. Further, there has been a huge amount of unpaid food subsidy to Food Corporation of India, i.e. to the tune of Rs. 23,699.62 crore (After adjustment from interim adjustment from LIC).
